segments.text: Is it running?
It is running.
Oh.
This is Alan Vines.
I want to start in or continue working on the period in which I was spending half time in Washington and half time in Woods Hole.
The advent of better instrumentation and of more laboratories getting involved in oceanography was very important.
Along about this time, Scripps got the RV Horizon.
so they could start making expeditions with really a much better capability than Atlantis was ever able to.
By this, they had a better choice of where they could go, how much they could carry, and so forth.
All of the

Of course, from where I sat in the working with the Bureau of Ships administering the laboratories, it seemed to me that the laboratories operated together and on a somewhat more centralized, not centralized plan, but the coordination was, it probably appeared better to me than it did to many other people because
So much of it was being operated out of our desk.
At that time, I would presume the budgets at Woods Hole were probably 80% from the Bureau of Ships.
And at Scripps, which had a great deal more state financing, it was probably lower and down around 60%.
possibly 50%.
During this period in the Woods Hole work, in our acoustic section, we were very heavily involved with convergent zone sonar and operated about
five major tests a year.
Brackett Hersey was in the acoustics work.
Brackett Hersey was my boss at Woods Hole.
He had taken over the acoustics and was chiefly responsible for the, deserves the principal credit for the high quality of acoustics work.
trying to keep it much more quantitative, certainly, than I ever would have.
Because I was more interested in the area, oceanographic aspects of the business.
And Hersey was more interested and involved in maintaining better acoustic measurements and keeping
information data that we got more creditable in the eyes of professional acousticians.
That doesn't mean that either one of us were negligent of the other aspects of it, but that tended to be somewhat of an automatic division of labor.
During this time, Islin was following the work very closely
advice, kibitzing, and helping us out on a little bit better general interpretation of how the ocean worked.
Also during this time, the Ewing and Warzel at the Lamont Laboratory, excuse me, at the Columbia Laboratory,
heavily involved in the transmission problem largely as it came out of geophysics.
And both Columbia and Woods Hole, largely through Hersey, were heavily involved in doing acoustical seismic tests and measurements.
Most of this was between
the United States and the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, because that was all the capability we had with our ships.
At that time, most of the seismic operations were two-ship operations involving one ship for shooting and one ship for receiving.
So the general attitude was to take Atlantis and whatever other ship we could get, and then as we
acquired more smaller ships, such as the Bear and Karen, we had a wider variety of ships.
But smaller ones were confined largely within the Great American Bight that is only out to Bermuda.
One word about the kinds of ships that were small ships that were used then.
Heaven knows they were as good as many of the boats that fishermen used.
So from that standpoint, we weren't badly abused.
But they were fairly small, running from 60 to 90 feet.
The amount of space on them was marginal, very marginal, from the standpoint of getting any reasonable amount of equipment aboard.
Those that were sailing ships had
booms and masts and stays in so many of the wrong places that they couldn't be used very efficiently.
And while most of them were safe enough as far as getting back, the weather didn't have to get very heavy, but they got to where it was just plain impossible to continue the work.
So the efficiency of these ships was not very high.
And it is
One of the reasons why, along about this time, I began to think much more that really the ship is the principal instrument.
And it was going to be pretty hard for us to do better work than the ship was capable of.
So I started spending much more time in the general concept of how can we improve ships, and how can we go about
getting better ones.
Didn't have to be very smart to do this because after you beat your brains out on inferior ships at sea, it looks like it's no good long-term solution for either you or the future of the game.
By this time it was
The general picture of the geology of the ocean was beginning to open up a good deal, the fact that there was a big lack of sediments in the ocean.
The group at Columbia was the ringleader in this, but it was becoming apparent from work that many people were doing.
ONR was moving along, picking up funding, and particularly the physical oceanography and biological end was doing very much more.
But they were quite slow in working and financing problems on instrumentation.
This tended to remain more in the Bureau of Ships budget
10 or 15 years later in the history of oceanography, ONR was carrying the burden in instrumentation.
And NSF was only hiring people or paying for ships.
At the present time, it's getting to where nobody wants to pay for advanced instrumentation.
And it is perhaps one reason why, at the moment, we may be on a little bit more of a technological plateau than is good for the science.
Washington was, as always, I suppose, organizing into committees.
There was a group established.
I can't think of their name right now.
In the oceanographic section, Dr. Redfield was the head of it, was the chairman of it.
They held meetings around the country with representatives from the laboratories, trying to put a little more coherence into the oceanographic plans.
This committee by itself did not really do a great deal of good, but it was useful in helping all laboratories get together and focus a little bit more
communication between labs.
And then, as it turned out, when the Korean War started, there was a little bit of a structure so that people knew who to talk to.
There was a format in which advice could be sent around in a semi-official fashion.
Lieutenant John Knauss, who was in the Office of Naval Research,
He was there about a year or so while I was still at the Bureau of Ships.
We spent a great deal of time together because John was a very alert young scientist who was disdained to go on in oceanography.
Particularly, we had been shipmates on a trip that

on the Atlantis, in which I was chief scientist down in the Cayman Trough operating out of Guantanamo, in which we were very much interested in the general current structure in the area south of Guantanamo as to how it might affect Navy tests in one way or another.
But this particular night in Washington, a short time after the Korean War broke out officially.
This was perhaps within the first day or second day.
John and I made a list of the sorts of things that oceanography needed in preparation for
for a much larger meeting the next day.
I've tried to find this piece of paper because it was really kind of interesting.
The principal things I can remember was that it was very clear that Woods Hole needed a building, needed more space.
It was very clear that the Columbia people needed a ship.
And it was very clear that Scripps needed more people.
This has nothing to do with the quality of the people at Scripps.
It was just merely that they had not built up as rapidly after the war as some of the other organizations.
And while they were very strong in some aspects of oceanography,
certainly needed more in the physical sense.
One of the advantages of having done a little bit of homework is that sometimes it is surprisingly how rapidly some of the suggestions get okayed and executed.
These Woods Hole did end up with their laboratory of oceanography, paid for by ONR,
Columbia got enough more money and enough assurance to where Ewing could get the VEMA and then utilize the Atlantis as a secondary ship rather than as a primary ship.
And without any question at all, the VEMA has been one of the great ships of America and of the oceanographic world in general in making the business global.

After leaving Washington and coming back to Woods Hole for full time, although I still spent quite a bit of time in Washington, the research work that I was primarily concerned with remained the instrumentation problems having to do with salinity corrected
sensors.
I believe I mentioned earlier that Carl Schleicher and Bradshaw had been hired to do this, and they carried it on with quiet distinction.
The other was variable depth sonar, and
Starting about this time, the Navy began to get a few experimental units.
And I spent a modest amount of time with the people in the fleet trying to sell it, write manuals for its use, and in general, try and help the Navy move in the direction of aerobatic sonar.
However, the convergent zone sonar and working with submarine people continued to be the principal thing I was interested in.
And about every two years, for a good many years, I started making a trip to Hawaii and working with
comm sub pack to help them use submarines, underwater sound and so forth, a little more efficiently with submarines.
This was a continuation of the work that I had done there during the war.
Submarine specific fleet was in many respects an easier organization to work with than
submarine's Atlantic fleet.
Because they were so much further away, they weren't bothered by as many people.
So when you did get out there, you found you generally got more cooperation.
They hadn't already been worn out by a dozen people just like you.
One of the other aspects was that the Pacific runs about half a mile deeper.
Certainly the Hawaiian area has deep water close at hand.

So many of the kinds of things we wanted to do, either for testing or demonstration, were much easier to do in local waters there than local waters off any of the submarine bases in continental United States.
Why don't you shut it down for a while?
Sure.
I have a series of questions to ask about this period we're talking about right now.
I have four questions, as a matter of fact, from both the previous tapes and this one.
First of all, now that ONR is beginning to carry more than its share of research,
What sort of oceanographers are they bringing into ONR, and whose policy is it to bring in what amounts to an oceanographer to work in an ONR desk with regularity?
Well, Revell moved over there.
I knew Revell went over there.
Revell went over there.
Then he got Gordon Lill as his right-hand man, who had been a bathymograph officer during the war.
And then he got Art Maxwell.
And this was the nucleus of their oceanographic group.
And back when there were so few of them, and the general picture was people took positive attitudes instead of negative attitudes.
Committees hadn't grown up yet.
They had a great deal of
of authority and exercise.
Is this on?
Yes.
So that is my, I think that is the story of ONR.
Then they started getting people, scientists from various laboratories, to come in and spend part time.
This was very good because it brought fresh people in for a while.
It also trained people.

I believe, as I said earlier, I can't emphasize too much the importance of having some of our brightest young people, at least while they're still in the impressionable age, to get them into a group where they have to think about a lot more than just themselves or just their laboratory and start devoting more of their time to the profession as a whole.
I think this was one of the reasons why
Why so much occurred at that time.
All right, now that anticipates my second question.
Is the bringing in of these people to work halftime in Onora, is this primarily a training process on Onora's part?
Does Ravel look upon this as a?
Oh, I don't think this was a training.
I think it was understood this would be one of the results of it.
But it was primarily a question of how do you get talent there?
oftentimes you'd bring people in who had specialties in a field that was real hot then.
If they were going to be in an ocean expedition, then you might get people to come down who were somewhat more specialists or involved in that particular part of the work.
So this rotation had a good deal to do
oftentimes had a good deal to do with the trend of the research, which also was the trend of the money.
Because oceanography really almost throughout its career, as I've known it, and particularly perhaps not quite so much now because we tend to have so many committees now,
But there would be sort of a base load for oceanography, of which the budget could stand about so much.
And this was generally for general purpose oceanography and for what you might call the highly organized oceanography.
Then special problems would come up.
For example, the discovery of convergent zone sonar was one.
That probably shoved a 30% trenchant into the budgeting of money.
And it allocated not narrowly, but at least broadly into one general field.
With discussions of things like the Indian Ocean Expedition, which kicked around for a couple of years to see whether people thought it made sense, and many people
Many people did not.
But it was an idea that would sell.
It was an idea that would keep the ships afloat, which is something the modern people have little comprehension about.
If a laboratory only has one ship, and you only see it's budgeting for it a couple of months in advance,
you think a lot harder about what can we do to get enough financing to where we can keep it going for a year or two at a time.
I think the budgeting of oceanography, and I don't mean just the budgeting.

I mean the way it worked, the way it brought in people, the way it sold itself, the way it convinced people that it was doing things, was to keep taking on programs, some of which were devised by individuals, others of which, say, the Indian Ocean was one.
Because it was clear we knew very little about the Indian Ocean.
I was not heavily involved in that except a little bit in the early planning.
I did not go on any of those Indian Ocean expeditions.
But our science knows so much more about the Indian Ocean because of that expedition, even though many people thought the original planning was very poor.
It at least happened.
I feel very strongly as a sort of a scientific thesis that Mother Nature puts out interesting things in white noise.
It is unlikely to...
It is so unlikely that we can have an ocean that is not interesting.
The ocean bottom, for example, is...
One of the reasons that I became interested in deep submersibles was discussions that the bottom of the ocean wasn't interesting just had to be wrong.
One couldn't conceive that 100 million square miles of ocean bottom wasn't going to have some extremely interesting places.
And any technique that would improve our ability to see
find points was important.
That next question?
Sure.
When do you begin to talk in the Bureau of Ships and ONR about the necessity for NSF?
Oh, this kind of thing was all level way over my head.
I was strictly a very junior member of the game there.
That kind of thing, people, well,
Ravel, for example, was in that circle.
Vannevar Bush was in that circle.
Some of these people, there were debates as to whether it made good sense or not.
But there was no question what some of the best scientific minds of the country were involved in.
But that was at several pecking orders higher than I was.
I was still a lucky young man who was in a good position.
How did you manage to keep such strong contacts with the Navy in any submarine warfare between 45 and 50?
Was it the contacts you primarily made in World War II?
It was the contacts which a great many people.
There were about half a dozen oceanographers who had been quite close to the submarine people.
And our principal contacts, permanent ones, were through the submarine people.
This rapidly grew.
The variable depth sonar brought us much more into destroyers.
Then a program which was undertaken I better be careful of the dates here, but undertaken in certainly the mid-50s was one that Hersey was

many of us were responsible for, but Hersey really took it under his wing, was explosive echo ranging and working with naval aviators so that they could try and do echo ranging using explosives as a source, using their sonoboys for receivers.
Here we cooperated closely with the Canadians, a great many of the American people, and our submarine people were also important because
Woods Hole had good contacts with the submarine people, and so we often got the targets for the aviators to work on.
Next question.
Those were the four questions I had.
I've obviously been talking with a very heavy strain of Navy here.
This did not occupy the majority of my time, although the Navy was the one that paid my salary and the one that I had the greatest concern with.
In my own case, we were spending a lot of time in instrumentation.
Incidentally, when I arrived at Woods Hole,
When Morris Ewing and I and Warzell arrived at Woods Hole, Woods Hole had almost no machinery.
I believe one small south bend lathe and one drill press.
Ewing and I had a small machine shop enough to both fill up and weight down a five-ton dump truck, which we brought up to Woods Hole with us for about...
Three years, that really was the Woods Hole shop was about 90% our personal shop.
We finally sold this machinery off, a little bit for the money, but primarily because we were convinced that if we left our machine shop there, the institution would never have a shop of its own.
And this forced them to go out and buy better equipment than they would have otherwise.
Why don't you shut it down?
